plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Conference Call of Intesa Sanpaolo for the presentation of the 2012 Half Yearly Results, hosted today by Mr. Enrico Cucchiani, Chief Executive Officer. My name is Clara and I would be your coordinator for today's conference. At the end of the presentation there would be a question-and-answer session. Today's conference is being recorded.
At this time I would like to hand the call over to Mr. Enrico Cucchiani. Sir, you may begin.

Hello. Good afternoon, good morning or whatever. Thank you for joining us on this call to discuss Intesa Sanpaolo's results for the first half of 2012. and I would like to especially thank the ones of you who are listening from a nice beach somewhere in the world and I would also like to thank the patient ones of you that are only a couple of conference calls away from a tropical beach. I'm Enrico Cucchiani, and I'm joined by Carlo Messina, our CFO.

I said at the Q1 stage that our strategy was focused on the de-risking, balance sheet strengthening, liquidity, superior execution and performance. Halfway through the year it is now clear that we are delivering on our promise. As we can see from the executive summary on page one, we have made considerable progress during the first half of the year, despite the ongoing recession and the associated credit quality deterioration.

We have continued to strengthen our balance sheet. The capital position has improved with the core Tier 1 ratio at 10.7% versus 10.1% at the end of 2011 and the EBA capital ratio is up at 10.1% versus 9.2% at the end of 2011. The leverage is deliberately low at 19.3; significantly lower than most of our international peers. The liquidity position is already compliant with Basel 3 requirements for 2018. Both liquidity coverage ratio and net stable funding ratio are above 100.

We have also further increased our loan provisions buffer. We have continued to deliver high quality earnings, almost €1.3 billion of net income for the semester, €470 million in Q2. Even on a normalized basis, H1 net income is solidly above €1 billion. Compared to last year, we delivered higher operating income, plus 2.6% and lower operating costs, minus 1.9%, which translates into a sound operating margin of €4.5 billion, that is plus 7.4% versus last year and let me say that this is the highest of the past eight semesters.

We addressed the deteriorating credit environment by increasing provisions faster than non-performing loss formation. We have also activated a set of short-term profit improvement levers, which have already delivered approximately €600 million before tax during the first semester on top of the buyback and the LTRO benefits. We have started a transformation journey to reposition the bank in order to deliver superior performance also in the new normal. Finally, in July, we conducted a successful buyback of €1.5 billion of debt, creating a pre-tax profit of €330 million, which of course doesn't show up yet in the results of the first half.

Let us now turn to page three, the core Tier 1 ratio has increased by 60 basis points from 10.1% at the end of 2011 to 10.7%, as I said before. Let me point out that this is the highest level among Italian banks and the second highest in the Eurozone. The EBA capital ratio has also increased by 90 basis points from 9.2% at the end of 2011 to 10.1% and to the best of our knowledge this is amongst the highest in the Eurozone as well.

Let us now turn to page four. As I have already mentioned we have kept our leverage at a very conservative level and as you can see from the slide, we are much below the average European leverage and one of the lowest in absolute terms.

Let us now turn to slide number five and take a look at our liquidity position. The liquidity position is very strong and has further improved during the semester. Since the beginning of the year, liquid assets have increased 14% to €111 billion. Unencumbered eligible assets with Central Banks, net of haircut, remained above €50 billion, a significantly buffer as recently recognized by the rating agencies.

The loans to deposit ratio is at 102% for the second quarter, down from 105% at the end of 2011. This improvement is mainly due to an increase in customer deposits, the increases being 2.5% versus the end of 2011. The high liquidity level, coupled with strong funding capabilities, makes Intesa a very compliant with Basel 3 requirements for 2018. In fact, both LCR and NSFR are well above 100%. To be more specific, NSFR is approximately at 108%.

Let us now turn to slide number six where we can appreciate the strength and quality of our provisioning. We continue to build up the stock of loan loss provisions, in particular, specific loan loss provisions stock went up by 12.5% in the last year, which to be precise is 20% higher on a like-for-like basis if you include the effect of the doubtful loans sale that we performed in recent months.

We also continued to build up our performing loans reserves, which increased by 8.5% in the last 12 months. Our non-performing loans coverage ratio has increased by 60 basis points from 44.6% at the end of the first half of 2011 to 45.2%, which is very conservative considering that our recovery rate is comfortably above 100%. In fact, it is at a 146% to be more specific.

Of course, one could question whether such a high recovery rate is sustainable. Let me just point out one fact. If we take, for instance, the average loan to value of our mortgage portfolio, we see that it is around 50%, loan to value as I said, 50%. This allows us to both maximize the recovery when a client becomes distressed and to have a very large buffer in case any realistic real estate deflation scenario. And incidentally, let me say that so far in Italy we are seeing only very modest declines in real estate prices.

In addition, we also have a comfortable €2.6 billion countercyclical buffer on performing loans, which has increased by 10 basis points to 80 basis points from 70 basis points a year ago. We have now analyzed the strength of our balance sheet and in particular of our capital position, of our liquidity and of our provisioning.

Let us now turn to the P&L and in particular to the Q2 results on slide number seven. We see a decline in operating income, in operating margin, in pre-tax income and in net income. However, I believe that these results are strong considering a few facts. First, the macro environment has deteriorated in a major way. GDP last year – has shrunk this year by 2.1%, while last year it was growing at 1%. The spread has ballooned from 160 basis points to 400, 500 basis points. Additionally, last year we had substantial one-offs such as the Prada IPO and the Findomestic sale which generated €426 million of operating income.

Finally, loan loss provisions have gone up by 31.5% during the second quarter. The good results of Q2 are on top of a good Q1, so let's now look at the performance of the entire first semester on slide number eight. The first half waterfall analysis confirms the quality of the results. The net income increased 3.6%, net fee and commission income was down 5.9% year-on-year due to a decrease in commissions from asset management and advisory, reflecting adverse market conditions.

Profits on trading were up 6.8% to €877 million, which benefited from capital gains of €274 million before tax, and there is a €183 million after-tax from the Tier 1 buyback in Q1 and benefited as well from €94 million from the sale of our participation in the London Stock Exchange, which took place in Q2. Insurance results have increased by 59% and all-in-all, operating income has increased by 2.6%.

Personnel and admin costs have significantly gone down, reflecting our focused cost reduction program. The resulting operating margin is a solid €4.5 billion, up 7.4% versus last year. Loan loss provisions for the semester reflect our prudent provisioning policy in a deteriorated environment and are up 36.5%, leading to a pre-tax income of €2.3 billion. Net income is at €1.3 billion, solidly above €1 billion even on a normalized basis.

Let us now turn to slide number nine. The waterfall analysis of net income development versus last year highlights the impact of our actions. We improved net interest income by €172 million through loan repricing and increased focus on deposits. We increased the insurance income by €168 million. We posted €550 million of additional provisions to face the challenging credit environment.

In addition, we enjoyed a one-off tax provision release of €173 million, for which of course we cannot claim any credit. However, let me point out that our tax rate after this one-off tax provision release is still high. Tax rates without the tax provision release would be 42%, with the tax provision release is 34%, but it's still higher than the European average which is 27%. All-in-all, our net income is only 9% lower than last year, despite 36.5% higher loan loss provisions.

Now let us turn to slide 10 to take a look at the return on sales. Very quickly on this indicator, which is generally not analyzed in banks. As you can see, the operating margin is at 50% and the cost/income ratio stands at 49.8%. The overall return on sales on a pre-tax basis is at 25%, a pretty high level in this market.

Now we can turn to slide 11 to look at the contribution by business unit. All business units showed positive contribution. Public finance included a unit which reported a very negative contribution in 2011 year-end results. Italian Retail remains stable versus last year, notwithstanding the low interest rate environment and indeed it has improved against the previous quarter. Italian Private Banking performed strongly versus first half of 2011 and CIB remains a strong contributor with excellent performance.

The International Subsidiary Division was down on the other side by 53%, compared to first half of last year, driven mainly by Hungary and in particular by the credit deterioration and the deleveraging taking place in that country and in that bank. Insurance business has showed a very strong performance versus the first half of 2011 growth, increasing by 124%.

Let us now take a look at the cost side on slide number 12. We have once again delivered an additional decrease in operating costs, which decreased by 1.9%, which is equivalent to €86 million in the first half of 2012. And, in fact, we see an acceleration of the improvement since in the second quarter year-on-year we had a decrease in operating costs of 2.2%.

Our aggressive cost containment measures delivered a 3.9% reduction in admin expenses, coupled with 1.4% reduction in personnel costs. This along with our topline growth leads to a best-in-class 49.8% cost/income ratio. It will be higher by year end, but Intesa will continue to be one of the lowest cost producer in the European landscape.

Let us now put this semester in the right perspective. As you can see on slide 13, Intesa has delivered the highest operating margin of the past eight semesters at €4.5 billion and let me point out that in 2012, in a very negative environment, the performance has been 17% higher than the average of the past four years. This is clearly encouraging and demonstrates our resilience despite the economic challenges.

Let us now focus again on credit quality and provisioning – that is on page 14. The prolonged negative macro-environment is generating further credit deterioration as evidenced by doubtful and substandard loans inflow, which shows an increase of 20%. To tackle this development, we have beefed up provisions by a significantly higher proportion, that is, we have beefed up provisions by 37% vis-à-vis an increase in inflow of 20%. However, we also have to point out that we see positive results from our dedicated NPL task force, of which we will talk later on in the presentation.

Growth rate in inflow of new, doubtful and substandard loans slowed down in Q2. The average for the semester has been 20%, but it was 25% in Q1 and is now down to 13% in Q2. The high cost of risk, of course, reflects the credit landscape and our very conservative and rigorous approach. Provisions on performing loans are best-in-class, I would say are best-in-class by a wide margin and are at 80 basis points, as I mentioned before.

Let us now quickly compare our performance to European peers. On page 15 we have very a synthetic ROE tree. Despite operating in a shrinking domestic economy our bank is performing better or in line with European peers on several KPIs. Loan loss provisions, which reflect the country-specific environment sandbag overall performance.

On the other side, we consider our low level of leverage a key strength in the current economic environment, despite the negative impact on pre-tax return on tangible equity, which is down to 14.4%, slightly below the European average. We have simulated the results applying average European provisioning levels. In this case, our return on tangible equity would be well above 17%, that is above European average.

Let's now do some benchmarking on efficiency. On slide 16, you can see that Intesa has the third lowest cost/income ratio among peers and shows the second best year-on-year improvement, reflecting our progress on both costs and income. Our cost/income will deteriorate slightly in the remainder of the year, but will continue to be at the bottom of the scale.

Let us now consider some of the short-term levers we implemented and the first steps of our transformation journey. Please bear with me and jump to slide number 18. Earlier this year, we committed to activate levers to improve short-term profitability and to develop a transformation program to reposition the bank to successfully compete in the "new normal" and I'm using this term "new normal" borrowing it from my former colleague, Mohammed Al-Arian. For the ones who might not be familiar with the term, it refers to the fact that the future macro landscape is going to be significantly different from the past and certainly not any better.

In the first half, we have implemented a full set of high impact short-term profit improvement measures that have already delivered substantial results as we will see in a minute. In addition, we have also started the transformation journey, have developed eight work streams to make Intesa more competitive. We have defined new performance management tools, key to foster a focused performance culture. And we have also simplified a focused structure and strengthened the management team.

Let us please turn to slide 19 to see the impact of our short-term levers. On slide 19, on the left-hand side we recap the promises and on the right-hand side we will see the delivery. We report a cumulative €300 million increase in net interest income from repricing. We have converted €665 million of capital that was tied up in activities generating negative EBA, converting them into value creating – converting the use of the capital into value creating activities. We keep our focus on aggressively reducing costs. We delivered cost reduction, as we said, of 1.9% in the first half, which translates in real money in €86 million of savings. And as I said, reduction is both in admin expenses. minus 3.9%, and personnel expenses, minus 1.4%.

Now we have 400 FTEs working as members of a task force activated on loan portfolio of €6 billion, okay, on non-performing – on problem loans, which are worth €6 billion and we have achieved already a release of €135 million in provisions. Finally, the net present value of our liquidity management program is now at €1.5 billion.

More details on liability management on slide number 20. This slide illustrates the key elements of our liability management and the way we have used the LTRO. We have issued three unsecured bonds between January and July for a total amount of €3.5 billion. Key message is, demand that was €8 billion and exceeded target by 125%. 70% of demand came from foreigners and also let me point out that we had great timing. For instance, the last bond was issued – was announced right after the June 29 summit when spreads were at a low point, and I point this out because it indicates that we have some smart guys and they are capable of very good execution.

We've also performed two successful buyback programs totaling €2.7 billion. €1.2 billion of Tier 1 subordinated notes was performed in February and €1.5 billion of senior notes and subordinated notes in July. We've also aggressively drawn down LTRO facilities for €36 billion.

In summary, great timing, excellent execution, important impact. First buyback €274 million capital gain before tax, second buyback in July not yet in the accounts you have seen, €330 million capital gain before tax. Overall, the net present value impact including the LTRO is approximately of €1.5 billion.

Now let me talk a little bit about the transformation journey. Our transformation journey includes eight strategic work streams, retail banking, corporate and investment banking, international subsidiaries, credit, operating costs, wealth management, product factories, digitalization. These are not just projects; they are pervasive work streams to revisit the delivery system of the bank. That is the way we operate and interact with the customers. As such, most of these work streams will generate the evolution of the business model and our operations over time in the coming years.

Let's now turn to slide number 22 to briefly discuss some important enablers from the transformation journey. Key enablers of the transformation journey are performance management tool and the development of a strong performance culture. We have developed a state-of-the-art performance measurement tool that allows us to measure at a very granular level, that is, when I say granular and modular level it means that we can measure it at divisional level, bank level, regional level, area level, branch level, what have you, okay. And we can measure and we can understand at the operational level again with the same granularity the full value chain. We can also benchmark our results against budget, against historical figures and against relevant competitors.

The newly developed tool supports a dynamic and effective performance dialog, where we have that – a top-down approach allows us to challenge the bottom-up planning. And, most important, we can have a strong focus for timely correction of problems and timely capture of opportunities.

Let me now talk briefly about organization and people and we can do so turning to page 23. Focus, simplicity, clarity, meritocracy are the guiding principles of the reorganization process. We have no major form of disruption of existing organization in order to minimize the shocks, that is, internal and external shocks. I've seen a lot of reorganizations when organizations are turned upside down, going from geographic to functional, to metrics, to whatever. Whenever you do something like that you have a prolonged period of total disruption, internal disruption and disruption in customer service.

I try to stay away from this and to upset the formal organization as little as possible. The focus is on significant simplification, clear focus and clarification of responsibilities. Sounds like plain vanilla, but I can assure you that in any large corporation, any complex organization there is a huge room for improvement just doing this basic – following this basic philosophy. And also I think that now we have some of the best senior executives in the industry placed in the key positions of our bank.

In addition, we are strengthening the bench, recruiting high profile potential with strong international background and they can be Italians or non-Italians, but they all have a strong multi-cultural background. They will be fully involved in the transformation journey and in the steer-in process and this will be a great chance to test them, to prepare them and test them for future larger responsibilities. Typical background of these people, ladies and gentlemen, will be a degree with highest honors from a top university, at least, I mean, a master degree, an MBA and possibly more than one from a top international business school, significant experience with a – typically with a professional firm, management consultants, commercial and major international commercial investment banks. And age-wise they would be late 30s to mid 40s.

Let us now turn to slide number 25 to talk a little bit about the outlook. First, the Eurozone, which seems a key driver of anything these days. The Eurozone, I would say, seems to be in a state of confusion and the roller coaster would be the best analogy of the Eurozone experience. However, despite this state of confusion we cannot suffer from myopia either and we cannot discount the positives. The Eurozone fundamentals continue to be strong and I would say they are the strongest among Western economies, our industrialized countries.

Political leadership is gradually, I mean to say slowly, but gradually it is developing awareness of the severe shortcomings in economic governance and is timidly, too timidly, but still it is committing to create the necessary infrastructure, that is banking union, fiscal union, finally political union. We are witnessing a tango dance, two steps forward, one back, but overall the direction seems clear. The real question mark is the sense of urgency and the execution capabilities.

Now a brief comment on Italy. The real economy, there is no doubt, is suffering from the continued recession and from the high spreads and credit quality reflects this sector. Credit quality has been deteriorating and I think the credit quality will continue to remain an issue beyond 2012. The political outlook is under development, but I am significantly more positive than the general perception outside of Italy, as here we can definitely sense a very concrete and mounting pressure on Mario Monti to stay on and to continue the turnaround program of the country, which he has successfully started, even though the job is far from finished.

Now a few words on Intesa and on our outlook for 2012. In this volatile environment, we forecast solid and reliable P&L results, backed by a strong and solid balance sheet. Core Tier 1 and common equity ratios are set to remain well above 10% and capital ratios well above the EBA threshold. Our conservative approach of low leverage and high liquidity is key in these uncertain times and generous provisioning provides a prudent and countercyclical buffer.

In other words, strong capital, high liquidity, redundant provision, and I underline the word redundant, okay, because I believe that we are particularly prudent in our provisioning. We could perhaps more easily present easier figures, but under the current uncertainties, I believe the redundancy is an important factor and for us is a priority. In addition, we maintain a very strong focus on performance, while starting to re-engineer the bank and preparing it for future challenges.

Let us not forget, and I'm sorry if I repeat myself that in July we conducted this successful buyback, which brings us €330 million before taxes of additional profit and which doesn't – hasn't shown up yet in the accounts.
And finally, our dividend will be at least equal to that of 2011 and I would say, with a generous dividend yield, at least at current prices and let me end on this note.
Let me thank you once again for your kind attention and we are now ready to take your questions.
Thank you. The first question comes from Ronny Rehn from KBW. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon and thanks for taking the time for the call. A few questions from me. The first one on the impaired loans. I can see that your impaired loans went up almost €2.3 billion in the quarter, which is we haven't seen that for a while. And your total adjustments for impaired loans went up €250 million and were basically helped by a release of performing loans represented by securities. And so, actually coverage in the quarter has declined overall by 2 percentage points. I just want to see how you tied it in with your comment of a very conservative provisioning policy? That's the first question.

And the second question is on funding cost sensitivity. You obviously heard from this ECB yesterday that they may, going forward, target the short end of the yield curve and we've seen some positive market reaction to that. What is your sort of sensitivity level to a 1 percentage point decline in the two-year bond yields in Italy?
And lastly, on the business plan targets as they stand, you're looking for flat costs by 2013, how much room for improvement do you see on that, your current target? Thank you.
I'm not so sure I've heard well the first couple of questions. I'll leave them to Carlo. I'm not so sure either where did you see our cost for 2013?
In the old business plan, you know?
The old business plan, but the old business plan has been pronounced dead.
Completely dead?

I think, I would say, quite a few months ago and hasn't been revived. So that is part of the "old normal". We are gearing up pretty aggressively for the "new normal". So please continue to expect a committed, determined, focused attitude at cost cutting in the coming months, in the coming years, at least as long as I'll be around, there'll be a very strong focus on cost cutting. Now perhaps, Carlo, I don't know if you have understood...

Sorry, I'll try to elaborate. I understood on the sensitivity related to the ECB news and the impact on the short-term part of the curve. In my opinion, the impact on the net interest margin of these maneuvers will not be so relevant. So we can confirm our sensitivity on the net interest margin, it is 100 basis points, €300 million of possible increase. Then you have to consider the mitigation that we can do looking at the repricing action that we have on the markup. But I ask you if it is possible to have some more details on your question, so I can ask...

Well, more details, I just want to see, obviously, there has been a lot of complaints in the market that the yields have gone too high and the funding costs have gone up, so I just thought if you get now some support from the ECB to at least bring the short-term end down of the yield curve, what kind of impact that might have, with a read across to retail bonds' deposit price?
So, looking at – yes, okay. So, I understand. So the real point is that looking at the sensitivity will remain what I told you.
Yes.

Looking at the retail bond funding, so looking at the – in the medium term part of the curve, in our opinion it is possible to have some benefit, you have to consider that in this moment there is a nice correlation between the spread BTP-bond and the retail medium-term cost of funding, as if you look also at the wholesale cost of funding is related with the spread BTP-bond. So, in my opinion, we can have some positive contribution from these statements from the ECB and we will see in the next month. But if you look at our funding plan, we are well above the target, so we can stay out of the market without any kind of problem for our liquidity.
Okay. And one quick question on the existing retail bonds, could you give us the current sort of average carry or average yields that you have on those retail bonds?
So the average cost of our retail bonds is in the range of 120 basis points.
The overall yield, what is the spread?
It is the spread on all our retail bonds.
Okay, great, thank you. And then just on the first question I had on the impaired loans, did you catch the question or you want me to repeat it?
Repeat it.

Okay, so impaired loans, total impaired loans went from €43 billion to – €43.3 billion to €45.6 billion, so €2.3 billion up and your total adjustment to loans went from €22.3 billion to €22.5 billion, so €200 million, €250 million up, so almost didn't go up at all. And the main item here which was positive was a release for loans represented by securities, performing loans. And so, how do we think about it? I mean how sustainable is that given the deterioration in the book, you might not be able to release this forever?

Sorry, I cannot understand your point. The dynamics of our non-performing loans was the one that we have in the figures in the presentation and considering the different items of our provisioning we had and a stable amount of generic provision and an 80 basis points of generic provision. So we have not any kind of release in our generic provisioning. So the increase in the gross non-performing loans is then related with the net – with increase in the net performing loans, having in mind the average coverage rate that you have in the presentation. So...
Okay. And maybe this is wrong in the Excel file. Then I'll follow up with IR on this, yeah. That's fine. Thank you very much for your answers.
Next, please?
The next question comes from Matteo Ghilotti from Equita. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Just a couple of questions. The first one is on the growth of gross total impaired loans, which were up 5% quarter-on-quarter. They were up 4% in the first quarter. So there was a mild acceleration in this dynamic. Just would like to have your sense on this growth rate, if you believe that it's going to accelerate further because of the recession in Italy, or you see more stabilization if you have any feeling about that?

And the second question is more a general question on some big positions, big tickets like Pesaro, Risanamento, just your feeling, if you believe you are still comfortable with the kind of, let's say, provision that you took or is it something that you could reconsider by the end of the year? Thank you.

Okay. So, I will answer to the first question and then I will leave our Chief Executive Officer to elaborate with the second. So looking at the first question, if you can go to page 55 of our presentation, so we can talk about figures, you have the amount of gross non-performing loans and then the amount of net non-performing loans. You have to consider that in the first quarter, we sold non-performing loan for an amount of – a gross amount of €1.6 billion, so you have to consider this amount into the dynamics of our stocks. And then if you go to the page 56, you have the inflows from the performing loans.

That is something that we consider in elaborating for the – for what would be the future amount of our non-performing loans. You can see that looking at the past due, we have an increase and it typical in this phase of the cycle, because we have the part of the credit that is deteriorating and you can see in the past due. But looking at non-performing loans, doubtful loans and substandard loans, the amount is – now the inflow are down compared with – versus first quarter 2012. So the point is that our view is that the amount can increase in the second part of the year, but not in a so relevant amount looking at actual figures.
Okay.

Okay. Concerning the big ticket items such as the Pesaro, first of all, let me tell you about our policy. When we see a problem or an issue our policy is to acknowledge it right away. Okay? Last year, we had a provision on Pesaro for approximately, if I remember correctly, €300 million, and we have checked of course against the current situation and we believe that it is perfectly adequate. In fact, I think we stand a chance to have a good recovery. We monitor the situation very carefully. There is the disposal of one asset, which – I mean the value is not yet totally clear. If it is at the upper range we will recover, I would say, almost all our provisions. If not, our provision should be adequate, at least that is our assessment for the time being. We are determined on all assets that could be associated with question marks; we have determined to proceed as firmly and as fast as possible without any discount, without any flexibility. Okay, the fact is that of course the market is what it is, but we are not timid in moving – in addressing these issues.
Thanks.
And I mean we will see next quarter and the following quarter or so, but we don't have a policy of postponing things. We acknowledge facts as we see them. Okay? Thank you.
Thank you. Very clear.
Next, please?
The next question comes from Francesca Tondi from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Thanks very much for the presentation. Couple of questions also on my side. I mean, first of all, there has been a lot of debate as to whether the ECB at some point may consider taking down the rate on the excess reserve and the deposits of the ECB into negative territory. If that were to be the case, what would be the impact for you in terms of profitability, if any, and how do you think at all you would react in terms of an ALM strategies in your treasury, that would be quite interesting? Is that relevant, or for you ultimately what is relevant really is the change in the rescue rate. With reference to that you just mentioned 100 basis points would give you about €300 million plus or minus net interest income. Is it correct to assume it's a plus or minus are parallel depending on whether rates at this point more likely will be going down, is that already net of hedges?

And then looking at your NPLs deterioration for this quarter, could you give us a little bit more color of where you have seen some of the changes? A lot of increase in the past dues seems to be concentrated there. Is it more corporate or SME, is it more household, and how do you see this behavior? Thank you.

So looking at the ECB negative rate, in my opinion what could change could be the amount of commercial papers that we can place on the institutional investors, so only in this case, in my opinion, we can have a positive impact, otherwise no change, no relevant change on our ALM strategy. Looking at the net interest margin...

Will you – sorry for interrupting – will you then be looking in a different way at your excess reserves, or no matter that you will still be happy to keep whatever that you have as excess reserve, if any?
Sorry, Francesca, I didn't understand that.
Yeah.
I didn't hear you very well.

Sorry, clearly the negative rate would likely be placed on the excess liquidity reserve that one has at the ECB. Would you change your strategy on the excess reserves, would you change your strategy on where you keep your liquidity, for example?

We don't have any kind of deposits with the ECB. So we will not have any impact with ECB because our liquidity reserve is mainly in short-term government bonds. So it is not a matter of having an impact on our asset size. What could we have, it could be an impact on our liability side, because in my opinion with a negative yield to the institutional investor or other investors that are depositing money through the banks in the ECB there could be a switch from ECB to wholesale funding for the good quality banks and so, in my opinion, we can have an increase in the commercial papers funding. So, looking at the asset size, in my opinion, we will not have any kind of impact.
Okay.

As a matter of fact, Francesca, if I may interject, there was something that was actually voiced from the sound banks to Mario Draghi encouraging him to move in this direction, so that we actually, we might be able to stimulate the wholesale interbank market, which is otherwise dead. We don't know if it will work or not, but it was actually one suggestion that was coming from some sound banks.
Thank you. Thank you.

So, coming back on sensitivity on net interest margin, the sensitivity is considering the hedging, so it's considering our actual hedging position. But as you know, this is only a formal indication, because in reality you have to consider the ability of the bank to manage markdown and markup. And as you know, we are in a very strong process of repricing with relevant impact that you can see in the presentation. Then answering to the last question, so looking at the – where we have the increase in past due is mainly related to the Banca dei Territori area, and in looking at the sectors in which we have past due is mainly concentrated in construction services and distribution.

Yes, however, I mean it's a relative concentration. I don't think that we have any alarming situation. What you actually – what you actually see is that the Italian companies that are very much in – engaged in international activities, exports, outside production and so on are not suffering, while the ones that have a domestic focus and domestic limitation, of course, are going down with economy. And I mean one of the things – I mean I know talking to you is stating the obvious, but one of the things that I try to explain to people that are not so familiar with the dynamics is when a country goes in a recession of, let's say, their GDP decreases by 2%, the fact is that 50% of the public sector is not affected, then there is a part of the public – private sector, such as agriculture and so on, where the output is not really affected. So that 2% becomes a 10% decline for a good part of the real economy and then of course is affecting the quality of the performance of this company, so their ability to repay loans, so that is the fact. And the fact that we have to address is that – which is a macro effect, we have to address the spread issue and I mean personally the – the way that I see out of the situation is that we – besides the technical things that have been discussed like the banking license to the ECM, the ability of the ECB to intervene, blah-blah-blah, but we really have to pressure the move towards greater integration in Europe, because otherwise we create distortions.

There is one economy, one large economy which is taking advantage of the subsidies deriving from negative interest rates and the other countries are paying a price that exceeds what should be the normal risk premium. So I think that – I mean we should not just be spectators and watch this show developing in a way that that is a little bit paradoxical and we have – I'm sorry, if I make this detour in this concord, but we have to have a reality check and just as you – sometimes you see that bubbles are formed because of the Herd syndrome, everybody goes after something that is unjustified by the fundamentals, sometimes the reverse is happening and I think we have to be among the ones that work to stop this.
